definition: To lessen in intensity or degree
example: The storm abated, and the sun came out.

definition: To formally renounce or reject something
example: The king abjured his claim to the throne.
The publisher had to abridge the novel for the children's edition.
The detective’s sharp acumen helped crack the case.
Taking aspirin can alleviate a headache.

definition: To merge or combine into one; unite
example: The company will amalgamate its two marketing departments for better efficiency.
The neighbors reached an amicable agreement regarding the property line.
The student's apathy towards learning was evident in his grades.
The brutality of the war appalled the entire world.

definition: To calm or pacify someone by giving them what they want
example: The king tried to appease the angry mob with promises of reform.
John was apprehensive about his upcoming presentation.

definition: To provide relief; to soothe or relieve
example: The letter assuaged her fears.

definition: Showing a willingness to take surprisingly bold risks; recklessly daring
example: Her audacious decision to skydive shocked her friends.
They chose an auspicious date for the wedding, hoping for good fortune.

definition: So lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring
example: The movie's plot was banal and predictable.

definition: To give a false impression; to disguise or contradict
example: His calm manner belied the nervousness he felt.
The belligerent customer argued with the store manager.
The benevolent woman spent her weekends volunteering at the shelter.
The new evidence helped bolster their case in court.
The politician’s bombastic speeches failed to impress the voters.
The city streets were filled with the cacophony of traffic.

definition: The rhythm or flow of sound
example: The poet used cadence to create a musical effect in his verses.
He appreciated her candour during their conversation.
The army had no choice but to capitulate to the enemy forces.
Her capricious nature made it difficult to anticipate her actions.
The comedian’s caustic remarks left the audience squirming.
She presented a cogent argument in favor of her proposal.

definition: Easy to see or notice; prominent
example: Her bright red dress made her conspicuous in the crowd.
The conundrum of balancing work and family life is a common challenge.
The illness debilitated him, and he was unable to work.
Smoking has deleterious effects on one’s health.
The artist delineated the features of the landscape.

definition: A situation where a difficult choice must be made between two equally undesirable options
example: He faced a dilemma: accept the promotion and move away or stay in his current city and miss out on the opportunity.
She looked at him with disdain after his rude comment.

definition: Insincere or misleading; lacking in candor
example: Her disingenuous apology only made things worse.
The two sisters had disparate interests and hobbies.

definition: Asserting opinions as if they were facts; rigidly opinionated
example: His dogmatic attitude made it difficult to have a constructive discussion.
She gave her best friend an effusive hug.
The team’s performance was egregious, resulting in a humiliating defeat.

definition: Ambiguous; open to more than one interpretation
example: The instructions were equivocal, leading to confusion.

definition: To draw out or evoke a response
example: The teacher used open-ended questions to elicit thoughtful answers from her students.

definition: Fluent or persuasive in speaking or writing
example: The speaker delivered an eloquent speech that moved the audience to tears.

definition: To weaken or sap the energy of
example: The long commute enervated her, leaving her too tired to cook dinner.
The enigmatic smile on her face left everyone curious.

definition: Lasting for a very short time
example: The beauty of the cherry blossoms is ephemeral.

definition: Having or showing great knowledge; learned or scholarly
example: The professor’s erudite lecture impressed the students.
The argument only exacerbated the already tense situation.

definition: Treating serious issues with inappropriate humor
example: His facetious remarks during the meeting were not appreciated.
She was fastidious about keeping her house clean.
He was a fervent supporter of human rights.
It was fortuitous that she found the lost keys.
The thief cast a furtive glance around before stealing the jewels.
The garrulous old man told stories for hours.
Mark was gregarious and made friends easily at the party.
The hapless traveler lost his wallet on the trip.
The haughty aristocrat looked down on those she considered beneath her.
Her histrionic reaction to the news startled everyone.
His hubris led to his downfall in the end.

definition: A person who attacks or criticizes cherished beliefs or institutions
example: The artist was considered an iconoclast for rejecting traditional painting styles.
He imbibed too much wine at the party and ended up with a headache the next day.

definition: A situation in which progress is impossible; a deadlock
example: The negotiations reached an impasse.

definition: Showing no emotion or feeling; indifferent
example: The actor remained impassive despite the chaos unfolding around him.
His impetuous decision led to regret later on.
It was imprudent of her to go swimming alone in the dark.
The incessant noise from the construction site was annoying.

definition: Emitting light as a result of being heated; glowing
example: The incandescent bulb illuminated the room.

definition: Too great or extreme to be expressed in words
example: The beauty of the sunset was ineffable.

definition: Tending to obstruct or harm; unfriendly or hostile
example: Lack of sleep is inimical to one's health.

definition: Harmless; not likely to irritate or offend
example: Though the joke was offensive to some, he believed it was innocuous.

definition: Proceeding in a gradual, subtle way (with harmful effects)
example: The insidious disease went undetected until it was too late.

definition: Lacking flavor, vigor, or interest; bland or dull
example: The soup was insipid and needed more spices.

definition: Seemingly endless; very long and tiring
example: The meeting seemed interminable, dragging on for hours.

definition: Unwilling to compromise or change one’s mind; stubborn
example: The intransigent leader refused to listen to any alternative solutions.

definition: To place side by side for comparison
example: The artist juxtaposed light and dark in her paintings.

definition: To ignite (also: to arouse or inspire)
example: The teacher hoped to kindle an interest in science among her students.

definition: The sound of a bell, especially when rung solemnly for a death or funeral
example: The knell of the church bell signaled the end of the service.
The detective gave a laconic response to the question.

definition: To mourn; express sorrow or regret
example: The villagers lamented the loss of their crops to the drought.
The hot weather made him feel languid and sleepy.

definition: To become weak or feeble; to lose strength
example: The plants began to languish during the drought.
After a heavy meal, he felt lethargic and sleepy.

definition: Very generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival or someone less powerful
example: He was magnanimous in victory, praising his opponent's effort.

definition: A general feeling of discomfort or unease
example: A sense of malaise hung over the city after the natural disaster.

definition: Paying great attention to detail; careful and precise
example: The scientist was meticulous in her lab work, ensuring accurate results.

definition: A person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society
example: He was a misanthrope who retreated to a cabin in the woods to avoid people.
The instructions were nebulous, leaving us confused.
He acted nonchalant about the news, but deep down, he was worried.

definition: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action
example: Despite the evidence, he remained obdurate in his stance.

definition: To make something unclear or difficult to understand
example: The politician’s answer obfuscated the real issue rather than addressing it directly.
She was so deep in thought that she was oblivious to her surroundings.

definition: Obedient or attentive to an excessive or servile degree
example: The obsequious assistant always agreed with his boss.

definition: Not transparent; not allowing light to pass through
example: The windows were opaque, preventing anyone from seeing inside.

definition: Apparent or seeming, but not necessarily true
example: His ostensible reason for being late was car trouble, but it was probably something else.
Her ostentatious display of wealth made others uncomfortable.
The discovery was a paradigm shift in the field of medicine.

definition: Overly concerned with minor details and rules; fussy
example: The professor’s pedantic lectures often bored his students.
The pernicious effects of smoking are well-documented.

definition: To make (someone) less angry or hostile; to calm
example: She tried to placate her friend with kind words after their argument.
His explanation seemed plausible, given the circumstances.

definition: Suggesting the occurrence of something important or ominous
example: The dark clouds were a portentous sign of an approaching storm.

definition: Happening suddenly or quickly (also: to cause to happen)
example: The king's precipitate decision to declare war shocked his advisors.
The stock market took a precipitous drop after the bad news.

definition: Acting with or showing care and thought for the future; wise
example: It's prudent to save money for emergencies.

definition: Dull, lacking in creativity or excitement; commonplace
example: His writing was prosaic, lacking any creative spark.
His querulous nature made him difficult to work with.

definition: To suppress; put an end to
example: The police were called to quell the riot.
The teacher gently rebuked the student for talking in class.
The book was filled with recondite philosophical concepts.
His actions were deemed reprehensible by society.

definition: Able to recover quickly from difficulties
example: Despite facing many setbacks, she remained resilient and optimistic.
She was reticent about discussing her personal life.
The sagacious old man gave valuable advice to the young prince.
The salient features of the proposal were highlighted.

definition: Optimistic or positive, especially in a bad or difficult situation
example: Despite the hardships, she remained sanguine about the future.

definition: Showing great care and persistent effort
example: He was a sedulous student who always went above and beyond.

definition: Showing care and concern for others; attentive
example: The nurse was solicitous of the patient’s needs.

definition: A speech delivered by a character alone on stage
example: The actor delivered a powerful soliloquy that revealed his character's inner turmoil.

definition: Superficially plausible, but actually wrong; misleadingly attractive
example: The argument sounded good, but it was specious.

definition: Not being what it purports to be; false or fake
example: The scientist quickly debunked the spurious claims in the article.

definition: Not showing feeling or emotion; unemotional
example: He remained stoic even when faced with great adversity.
The king lived a sumptuous life in his palace.

definition: Behaving as if one is superior to others; arrogant
example: The professor’s supercilious attitude alienated his students.
The extra decorations were superfluous and cluttered the room.
She made a surreptitious exit from the party.
The taciturn man preferred listening to speaking.
She was tenacious in her pursuit of a career in medicine.
The evidence supporting their claim was very tenuous.

definition: Lasting for only a short time
example: The transient feeling of happiness soon faded away.

definition: Being everywhere at the same time
example: In today’s world, smartphones are ubiquitous.
The committee reached a unanimous decision.

definition: To waver between different opinions or actions
example: He vacillated between accepting the job offer and staying in his current position.

definition: Having or showing a lack of thought or intelligence; mindless
example: The interviewer's vacuous questions frustrated the scientist.
He was vehement in his opposition to the proposal.

definition: Worthy of respect due to age, wisdom, or character
example: The venerable professor had taught at the university for over 50 years.

definition: To decrease gradually in size or intensity
example: The moon’s brightness began to wane as it entered its last phase.
She was wary of strangers offering her help.
As she looked at the old photographs, she felt wistful.

definition: A person who is attracted to foreign cultures or people
example: As a xenophile, she loved traveling and experiencing new cultures.

definition: Fear or hatred of foreigners or strangers
example: The rise of xenophobia in the country was concerning.

definition: To have a strong desire or longing
example: He yearned for adventure and travel.
She tackled her new project with great zeal.
The volunteers were zealous in their efforts to help.
